user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 14.3 is: Controlling expressions shall not be invariant.
Here are exceptions to this rule:
1. Invariants that are used to create infinite loops are permitted.
2. A do-while loop with an essentially Boolean controlling expression that evaluates to false and satisfies the constraints and semantics for an integer constant expression is permitted.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of digest_reset:
```c
_MHD_static_inline void
digest_reset (struct DigestAlgorithm *da)
{
  mhd_assert (! da->uninitialised);
  mhd_assert (da->algo_selected);
  mhd_assert (! da->hashing);
#ifdef MHD_MD5_SUPPORT
  if (MHD_DIGEST_BASE_ALGO_MD5 == da->algo)
  {
#ifdef MHD_MD5_HAS_FINISH
    mhd_assert (! da->ready_for_hashing);
#else  /* ! MHD_MD5_HAS_FINISH */
    mhd_assert (da->ready_for_hashing);
#endif /* ! MHD_MD5_HAS_FINISH */
    MHD_MD5_reset (&da->ctx.md5_ctx);
#ifdef _DEBUG
    da->ready_for_hashing = true;
#endif /* _DEBUG */
  }
  else
#endif /* MHD_MD5_SUPPORT */
#ifdef MHD_SHA256_SUPPORT
  if (MHD_DIGEST_BASE_ALGO_SHA256 == da->algo)
  {
#ifdef MHD_SHA256_HAS_FINISH
    mhd_assert (! da->ready_for_hashing);
#else  /* ! MHD_SHA256_HAS_FINISH */
    mhd_assert (da->ready_for_hashing);
#endif /* ! MHD_SHA256_HAS_FINISH */
    MHD_SHA256_reset (&da->ctx.sha256_ctx);
#ifdef _DEBUG
    da->ready_for_hashing = true;
#endif /* _DEBUG */
  }
  else
#endif /* MHD_SHA256_SUPPORT */
#ifdef MHD_SHA512_256_SUPPORT
  if (MHD_DIGEST_BASE_ALGO_SHA512_256 == da->algo)
  {
    mhd_assert (! da->ready_for_hashing);
    MHD_SHA512_256_init (&da->ctx.sha512_256_ctx);
#ifdef _DEBUG
    da->ready_for_hashing = true;
#endif
  }
  else
#endif /* MHD_SHA512_256_SUPPORT */
  {
#ifdef _DEBUG
    da->ready_for_hashing = false;
#endif
    mhd_assert (0); /* May not happen, bad algorithm */
  }
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function digest_reset:
struct DigestAlgorithm
{
  /**
   * A context for the digest algorithm, already initialized to be
   * useful for @e init, @e update and @e digest.
   */
  union DigestCtx ctx;

  /**
   * The hash calculation algorithm.
   */
  enum MHD_DigestBaseAlgo algo;

  /**
   * Buffer for hex-print of the final digest.
   */
#ifdef _DEBUG
  bool uninitialised; /**< The structure has been not set-up */
  bool algo_selected; /**< The algorithm has been selected */
  bool ready_for_hashing; /**< The structure is ready to hash data */
  bool hashing; /**< Some data has been hashed, but the digest has not finalised yet */
#endif /* _DEBUG */
}
...
#define mhd_assert(ignore) ((void)0)
...
#define MHD_MD5_SUPPORT 1
...
#define MHD_SHA256_SUPPORT 1
...
#define MHD_SHA512_256_SUPPORT 1
...
#define MHD_MD5_HAS_FINISH 1
...
#define MHD_SHA256_HAS_FINISH 1
...
#define MHD_MD5_reset(ctx) MHD_MD5_init(ctx)
...
#define MHD_SHA256_reset(ctx) MHD_SHA256_init(ctx)
...
void
MHD_SHA512_256_init (struct Sha512_256Ctx *ctx)
{
  /* Initial hash values, see FIPS PUB 180-4 clause 5.3.6.2 */
  /* Values generated by "IV Generation Function" as described in
   * clause 5.3.6 */
  ctx->H[0] = UINT64_C (0x22312194FC2BF72C);
  ctx->H[1] = UINT64_C (0x9F555FA3C84C64C2);
  ctx->H[2] = UINT64_C (0x2393B86B6F53B151);
  ctx->H[3] = UINT64_C (0x963877195940EABD);
  ctx->H[4] = UINT64_C (0x96283EE2A88EFFE3);
  ctx->H[5] = UINT64_C (0xBE5E1E2553863992);
  ctx->H[6] = UINT64_C (0x2B0199FC2C85B8AA);
  ctx->H[7] = UINT64_C (0x0EB72DDC81C52CA2);

  /* Initialise number of bytes and high part of number of bits. */
  ctx->count = 0;
  ctx->count_bits_hi = 0;
}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
No invariant controlling expressions were found that require investigation under MISRA C 2023 Rule 14.3. Rationale:

- The only C-level conditional expressions in digest_reset are comparisons of the runtime field da->algo against enumeration constants (e.g. MHD_DIGEST_BASE_ALGO_MD5 == da->algo). These depend on a non-constant struct member and therefore are not invariant.

- All #ifdef / #else / #endif constructs are preprocessor directives (compile-time inclusion/exclusion), not C controlling expressions governed by Rule 14.3.

- The mhd_assert(...) uses are macros defined as ((void)0) in the provided configuration, so they do not introduce controlling expressions in the compiled code; the asserted expressions are not used to control flow at runtime in this build.

- There are no loops (for/while/do-while) with constant controlling expressions in the function. The function does not create infinite loops (the allowed exception) nor use a do-while with an essentially Boolean constant control.

- Calls and macros such as MHD_MD5_reset, MHD_SHA256_reset, and MHD_SHA512_256_init are function/macro invocations that do not create controlling expressions.

Therefore no code fragments in the provided function appear to violate Rule 14.3 and nothing else needs to be investigated for this rule.
